item.description:
In 1942, a US Army B-18 Bolo bomber crashed on the side of Mt Waternomee, part of Moosilauke's Blue Ridge.The Crash Report


The crash site can be reached by following an old trail up from a logging road off NH rt 118.

This hike starts on Walker Brook Road, then follows the unmaintained B18 Crash Trail part way up Mount Waternomee to the place where a Douglas B18-A bomber plane crashed in 1942.

Remnants of the plane as well as a plaque are located at this site.

Start at the Walker brook road, near the bottom of 118 by the junction with 112.
It's gated, so park there and walk to the end of the road, where it crosses a stream without a bridge.
From there, follow the well established herd path to the crash site. It's pretty obvious these days, not much of a bush wack.


Features: Plane crash site, brooks, waterfall
Distance: 4.6 miles
Elevation Gain: 1350 feet (cumulative)
Hiking Time: Typical: 3:00
Outing Duration: Typical: 4:30
We will end this trip at the Woodstock Brewery or other local eatery.


We do not know what condition the trail will be in. Pack foot traction so you will be ready in case there is ice.



* Walk past the gate and continue walking along Walker Brook Road for 0.9 mile until it ends at a circular field.
* Turn right onto a trail that should be marked with a small cairn and/or surveyor's ribbon. This turn is at about the 1 o'clock position when you enter the field; or northwest if you prefer to use a compass.
* Walk for about 0.3 mile, then cross the brook (a tributary to Walker Brook) at a point where there is a metal stake with survey ribbon on the far side of the stream.
* You are now 1.1 miles away from the wreckage site. You will first parallel the stream, and then climb some, and then the trail levels out for a bit. At the end of this level area, be on the lookout for a tall waterfall that will only be partially visible through the woods. Then climb steeply up the trail, the rest of the way to the crash site.
* Be sure to keep walking in order to see all the plane remnants. You will first encounter the engines, then a boulder with a memorial plaque, and the wings will be farther up.
* After exploring, retrace your footsteps to return to your vehicle.



Leg gaitors in case the trail is wet/buggy
item.how_to_find_us: At trailhead. Trailhead is not far from hwy 112. if your early, watch for a small gated trailhead.
item.name: Mt Waternomee crash site
